Background On March 23, 2009, a Joint Declaration was signed between the European Commission (EC) and the Government of Ukraine with the intent to gradually integrate Ukraine into the single energy market of the European Union (EU), via membership of the Energy Community. On July 31, 2009, the Government of Ukraine and the EC, the World Bank, EBRD and EIB signed a Joint Declaration regarding "Support to Gas Sector Reform in Ukraine and the Purchase of Gas from Russia". The EC and IFIs (World Bank, EBRD, EIB) further reiterated their technical and financial support to Ukraine to reform and restructure the gas sector and modernize the gas infrastructure. On September 24, 2010, Ukraine signed the Protocol Concerning the Accession of Ukraine to the Treaty Establishing the Energy Community which was ratified by Parliament on December 15, 2010. In order to promote the implementation of the Joint Declaration and to enable Naftogaz and the IFIs (EBRD, EIB and the World Bank) to prepare and carry out investment projects to modernize the Ukrainian gas network and advise on gas sector reform and restructuring, an EC and World Bank financed and World Bank managed Trust Fund - Ukraine Gas will be established. B. Objectives Objectives of Ukraine Gas Trust Fund The objectives of the Trust Fund are to: 1) Support the Government of Ukraine to develop and implement key reforms in the gas sector in the framework of membership of the Energy Community and that are necessary for the IFI's (EBRD, EIB, World Bank) to be in a position to consider financial support for the modernization of the Ukraine Gas Transit System, including the corporate restructuring and financial transparency of Naftogaz. 2) Strengthen a Project Implementation Unit (PIU) in Naftogaz so it has the capacity to implement bankable projects with IFIs. 2. Trust Fund Scope and Components A. Background The aim of the Trust Fund is to provide advisory services and technical assistance to Naftogaz and the Government of Ukraine. The scope of the trust fund includes: * Technical assistance to Naftogaz to prepare bankable gas modernization projects to be financed by IFIs; and * Technical assistance to the Ministry of Energy and Coal Industries and Naftogaz in the implementation of gas sector reforms in the framework of membership of the Energy

The aim of thIs task is to hire experienced consultants to provide expert capacity building support to the PIU within Naftogaz in preparing and implementing projects wi th EIB, EBRD and World B nk i i the context of the overall gas modernization program, including capacity building to the I IU to enable it to prepare and implement the so-called Emergency Project to be finan(ed l,y EBRD and EIB and the broader Gas Transit System Modernization Proje-t. It is en iisaj ed that the minimum staffing requirement for the PIU include a PIU head; an expert on hydrocarbons transportation, long haul pipeline constructions and trunk pip,line s compressor stations; Pipeline transport IT and communication expert(s); Enironnental and social expert(s); Procurement specialist; Financial management specialist; L:-gal specialist; Interpreter / translator; Project assistant; Driver. This component will be implemented in accordance with the Terms of Reference on procurement and project management consultant services for the Project "Modernization and rehabilitation of gas pipeline Urengoy - Pomary - Uzhgorod" (UPU)" dated September 11, 2012, agreed between the Bank and the Ministry of Energy and Coal Industry of Ukraine, as the same may be updated with the prior approval of the Bank and in consultation with the European Commission. B.II: Component B: Advisory Services to the Ministry of Energy and Coal Industries in the Implementation of Outstanding Conditionalities related to gas sector reforms and the corporate restructuring and financial transparency of Naftogaz Task II: Reforming the Gas sector of Ukraine, including its institutional structure and corporate and financial restructuring plan for Naftogaz Background On September 24, 2010, Ukraine signed a Protocol on the accession of Ukraine to the Energy Community. On December 15, 2010, the Ukrainian Parliament ratified the Energy Community Treaty. As a party to the Treaty, Ukraine has a binding obligation to implement Directive 2003/55/EC concerning common rules for the internal market in natural gas, Directive 2004/67/EC concerning measures to safeguard security of natural gas supply and Regulation 1775/2005 on conditions for access to the natural gas transmission networks and thereby put in place a sound and transparent gas market structure. This requires the unbundling of Naftogaz according to the Gas Directive. Regarding steps to fulfil its commitments under the Energy Community Treaty in the gas sector, Ukraine passed a gas law in 2010. In 2012 the Parliament adopted amendments to the Laws "On Management of State Property Objects" and on "On Pipeline Transport" to allow the for the reorganisation of the state company NJSC "Naftogas of Ukraine" and its subsidiaries/affiliated companies in order to implement the provisions of the second and third gas directives. Resolution no. 360-p "On Restructuring of Subsidiary Companies of the NJSC "Naftogas of Ukraine" of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine of June 13, 2012 instructed the Ministry of Energy and Coal Industry/NJSC "Naftogas of Ukraine" to reform the subsidiaries companies "Ukrtransgaz" (gas transit) and "Ukrgazvydobyvannya" (gas production) into public joint stock companies. The Action Plan Q

It will also assist the Ministry of Energy ai id Coal Industries and Naftogaz to prepare and adopt a corporate and financial restructu -ing plan for Naftogaz' transmission, storage and distribution businesses and support the reform of Naftogaz. Task III: Implemeatation of E7xtr active Industry Transparency Initiative (EITI) Background On September 30, 2C09, the Ca>inel of Ministers of Ukraine adopted Resolution #1098 "On joining the Extractive Industries Trar sparency Initiative". The resolution states that in order to inprove managemen: practices in tf e extractive industries, improve the investment climate, combat corruption, ensure the )arti zipation of civil society in the monitoring of financial flows to the state budget, the Cz bine t of Ministers (a) approve to join EITI; (b) establish that first Vice Prime Minister of Uk-ain is ex officio Commissioner of the Cabinet of Ministers 9

The inter-ministerial working group on the EITI was created and met for the first time on March 1, 2012 including civil society representatives. On March 30, the World Bank received a request from the Ministry of Energy and Coal Industries (MoECI) for assistance with the creation of the multi-stakeholder group (MSG), including representatives of government, businesses and civil society. In August 2012, the MoECI invited civil society and oil and gas companies to submit their nominations to the MSG.
